item.title: If Ukraine had been a member of NATO, Vladimir Putin would have “thought twice” before starting a war, argues America’s former ambassador to the organisation in a guest commentary for The Economist https://t.co/bWgyf3fByl

“We believe in victory. It’s impossible to believe in anything else.” Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, speaks to The Economist’s editor-in-chief @zannymb and Russia editor @arkadyostrovsky, on a special episode of “The Economist Asks” podcast https://t.co/b10socDcxz
It is clear that Russia’s military top brass are suffering unusual attrition. Why? https://t.co/ySmtfxtEYo
It is the American president who seems frightened of tangling with Vladimir Putin, not the other way around https://t.co/OALNayA7gT

The Economist’s editor-in-chief, Zanny Minton Beddoes, travelled to the heart of the Ukrainian war effort to interview Volodymyr Zelensky.
In a wide-ranging interview, the Ukrainian president discussed the state of the war and why Putin must be defeated https://t.co/dmx8o1aGfr
The goal of a spin dictator is to appear to allow political competition while making it nearly impossible in practice https://t.co/UdEh6wv86A
Ukraine has won the first phase of the war simply by surviving. Now it needs to advance, and so Volodymyr Zelensky needs redoubled Western help https://t.co/FRpjQ86jB2
What does Volodymyr Zelensky believe victory will look like? “Victory is being able to save as many lives as possible...because without this nothing would make sense.” https://t.co/8tEVpLW6NR
Judges from Britain’s highest court have been doing double duty on Hong Kong’s since 1997. But this legacy of the city’s past will not feature in its future https://t.co/X4UwUhXwKh

The female literacy rate in Afghanistan more than doubled between 2000 and 2018 to 30%. Now a generation of girls is falling behind https://t.co/RLnlOo8Xsk
Economists in the Biden administration have calculated that the 400 wealthiest American families pay an average federal income-tax rate of just 8% https://t.co/5qrr3MQe8l
Not only could a victory for Ukraine against Russia invigorate the cause of democracy, but it would also enhance European security https://t.co/KJ8279kljU

On March 25th Zanny Minton Beddoes, editor-in-chief of The Economist, travelled to Kyiv to interview Volodymyr Zelensky.
Here is the inside story of how she and Arkady Ostrovsky, The Economist’s Russia editor, made it into the Ukrainian president’s war room https://t.co/HHJ1cuYUmD

A decisive victory for Ukraine would deter yet another Russian invasion. The more convincingly Ukraine can see off the Russian army, the more able it will be to resist the compromises that could poison the peace https://t.co/01t5GR3R1i
